questions.text: In the experiment shown below, what role does the whistle play?
questions.solution:
The experiment shown in the image is that of classical conditioning by Ivan Pavlov. The whistle plays the role of a conditional stimulus.

Classical conditioning is the theory of learning where neutral stimuli are associated with psychologically significant events.

Events in the Pavlov experiment:

  • Food - Unconditional stimulus (Option B) as it elicits salivation before the experiment commences
  • Response to food - Salivation as a result of the unconditional stimulus is the unconditional response (Option A) as it is elicited before the commencement of the experiment.
  • Bell/Whistle - Conditional stimulus as it elicits salivation conditional to the pairing of the bell and food
  • Response to the bell/whistle - This is known as the conditional response (Option C) as the dog has been conditioned to react to the conditional stimulus.

This model usually deals with involuntary responses. It is also called learning by association or respondent conditioning. He's also known for his work on the physiology of digestion

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of erratic behaviour in school. He is unable to sit still in class for more than a few minutes at a time, pushes other children, never waits for his turn, and disturbs his classmates. His parents say that he is hyperactive at home as well. The language and milestones are appropriate for his age. Any of the following drugs can be used in his condition except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above of a child with inattention and hyperactivity points towards a diagnosis of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Tricyclic antidepressants like desipramine are not recommended in the treatment of ADHD due to potential cardiac arrhythmia effects. There have been reports of sudden death in children with ADHD being treated with desipramine.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may disappear in some cases, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

questions.text: A female patient presents with disturbed sleep and difficulty concentrating at work for several months. She awakens early and feels fatigued all day. She is too anxious to fall asleep because she believes her neighborhood is unsafe. She is a single parent and worries about her son's school performance and their finances. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

Generalized anxiety disorder is defined as excessive anxiety and worry about several events or activities for most days during at least a 6-month period.

It is more commonly seen in females, with onset usually in teenage or early adult life. It is often seen coexisting with another anxiety disorder (such as social phobia, specific phobia, panic disorder), major depressive disorder, or substance abuse disorder. 

Areas of the brain implicated in the pathogenesis of generalized anxiety disorder include the occipital lobe, basal ganglia, the limbic system, and the frontal cortex.

Diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder is made using the DSM-V criteria-

  1. Excessive anxiety and worry about a number of events, occurring more days than not for at least 6 months, about a number of events or activities.
  2. Difficulty in controlling the worry.
  3. The anxiety and worry are associated with three or more of the following six symptoms (with at least some symptoms having been present for more days than not for the past 6 months):
    1. Restlessness or feeling keyed up or on edge
    2. Being easily fatigued
    3. Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
    4. Irritability
    5. Muscle tension
    6. Sleep disturbance (difficulty falling or staying asleep, or restless, unsatisfying sleep).
  4. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.
  5. The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition
  6. The disturbance is not better explained by another medical disorder.  

Treatment of generalized anxiety disorder includes psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy including benzodiazepines, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, buspirone, and venlafaxine.  

Other options:

Option B: Dependent personality disorder (DPD) is an anxious personality disorder characterized by an inability to be alone. People with DPD develop symptoms of anxiety when they’re not around others. They rely on other people for comfort, reassurance, advice, and support.

Option C: Social anxiety disorder/social phobia specifically involves the fear of social situations, unlike general anxiety disorder which involves anxiety about a lot of different things.

Option D: Panic disorder includes episodes of acute intense attacks of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. Generalized anxiety disorder is often confused with panic disorder and can be differentiated by the absence of spontaneous panic attacks.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a man with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse is suggestive of satyriasis. 

Satyriasis refers to uncontrollable or excessive sexual desire (hypersexuality) in males. It is also known as Don Juanism. Don Juan is a legendary, fictional libertine who devoted his life to seducing women.

In patients with this condition, sexual activity is usually a means to mask their deep feelings of inferiority. Some patients may have unconscious homosexual impulses, which they deny through compulsive sexual contact with women. They are usually not interested in women after sex.

Other options: 

Option B: Frotteurism is a form of paraphilic disorder, wherein the affected male achieves sexual gratification by rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman, usually in crowded places.

Option C: Nymphomania refers to excessive sexual desire or hypersexuality in women. It is a form of sexual addiction. 

Option D: Sexual masochism is a form of paraphilia, wherein the individual has sexual fantasies or urges that involve acts of being beaten, bound, or humiliated. It is more commonly seen in men.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with excessive stress and anxiety for 2 months. She had witnessed major bomb blasts in her city, and her symptoms appeared after the incident.  The psychiatrist diagnosed her with post-traumatic stress disorder. Which of the following is not an intrusion symptom of this disorder?

choices.text: Recurrent distressing memories and dreams of the traumatic event
Dissociative reactions in which the individual feels as if the traumatic event is recurring
Dissociative amnesia in which a person cannot remember the traumatic event
Physiological reactions to things that symbolise the traumatic event

questions.solution:
In the case of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), Dissociative amnesia occurs as a part of negative alterations in cognition and it is not an intrusion symptom.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (Ex:- witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). For a diagnosis of PTSD, the distressing symptoms must be present for more than one month. The symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

Intrusion symptoms: 

  • Recurrent distressing memories and dreams related to the traumatic event
  • Dissociative reactions (e.g., flashbacks) in which the individual feels as if the traumatic event is recurring
  • Intense psychological distress on exposure to cues associated with the traumatic event.

Avoidance symptoms: 

  • Avoidance of distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about the traumatic event
  • Avoidance of external reminders (people, places, conversations, activities, objects, situations) of the traumatic event.

Negative alterations in cognitions:

  • Dissociative amnesia
  • Negative beliefs or expectations about oneself or the world
  • Persistent negative emotional state, detachment.

Alterations in arousal:

  • Irritable behavior and angry outbursts
  • Hypervigilance
  • Exaggerated startle response.

Psychotherapies that are effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who has been diagnosed with Tourette's disorder keeps shouting and speaking obscene words and phrases abruptly in the classroom. What is this tic known as?
questions.solution:
The use of obscene words or phrases, seen in this child with Tourette's disorder, is known as Coprolalia.

Coprolalia is a complex vocal tic characterized by the involuntary and repetitive use of obscene or socially unacceptable words or phrases. Mental coprolalia, which is more common in Tourette's disorder than coprolalia, involves the sudden intrusion of obscene words into the patient's mind. Coprolalia can also be seen in some cases of schizophrenia.

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterised by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations called tics. The average age of onset of tics is between 4 years and 6 years of age, although the peak age for the severity of tics is between 10 and 12 years. The onset of tics is seen before the age of 18 years, and the tics may wax and wane in frequency. Over half of the children diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome also meet the criteria for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD).

For a diagnosis of Tourette's disorder, based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 (DSM-5) criteria, the presence of at least 2 motor tics along with at least 1 vocal tic persisting for a period greater than 12 months is required.

Behavioural interventions like habit reversal, comprehensive behavioural intervention, and exposure and response prevention are the first lines of treatment. Pharmacotherapy must be included in severe cases when they cause social and emotional problems, depression, or isolation. First-line agents are antipsychotics like aripiprazole and risperidone or noradrenergic agents like atomoxetine, clonidine, and guanfacine, which can be used as adjunctive for comorbid ADHD. Alternative treatments are tetrabenazine, topiramate, and tetrahydrocannabinol.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to child psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive non-verbal gestures for communication. His parents also mention that he prefers to be alone in school always and does not interact with any of his peers. He has very restricted interests in activities. His IQ level, cognitive development, and language skills are normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 5-year-old boy with repetitive non-verbal gestures for communication, impaired peer relationships, and restricted interest in activities with a normal IQ and language skills points towards a diagnosis of Asperger syndrome.

Asperger syndrome is an autistic spectrum disorder characterised by a wide range of impairments in social communication and restricted and repetitive behaviours. The aetiology is complex, with genetic and potentially environmental and perinatal contributions. It predominantly affects boys after 3 years of age. It is usually not associated with mental retardation, and a normal IQ, along with competencies in social skills, is considered a good prognostic factor.

Asperger syndrome is characterised by:

  • Impairment in social interaction and development:
    • markedly abnormal nonverbal communicative gestures
    • failure to develop peer relationships at the expected level
  • Restricted interests and patterns of behaviour
  • No significant delay in language, clinically significant cognitive delay, or adaptive impairment

Treatment of Asperger's syndrome involves promoting social communication and peer relationships. Very often, these children are highly verbal and have excellent academic achievement. To help these individuals in social and work settings, self-sufficiency and problem-solving techniques can be utilised.

As per the current updates (DSM-5), autism spectrum disorder (ASD) includes several conditions that are characterized by early onset of severe delay in the development of social and communicative skills and also unusual responses to the environment.

The diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder are as follows:

  1. Persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts
  2. Restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour, interests, or activities
  3. Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period
  4. Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of social functioning
  5. These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability or global developmental delay.

Other options:

Option A: Rett’s syndrome is seen exclusively in girls, where deterioration of developmental milestones, head circumference, and overall growth occurs after 5 months of age. The absence of such a history of deterioration from previous normal development, along with the absence of other characteristic features of Rett's syndrome like- stereotypic motions (eg-hand wringing), poor coordination, ataxia, complete loss of verbal abilities, respiratory difficulties, and seizures makes a diagnosis of Rett syndrome unlikely. 

Options C & D: Heller syndrome/Childhood disintegrative disorder, occurring between the ages of 3–5 years, is characterized by a significant developmental regression after a period of normal development for at least two years. This results in a deterioration of behavioural and adaptive functioning, including self-help skills, with loss of language and social skills, along with stereotyped movements and compulsive behaviour. The absence of these features makes a diagnosis of Childhood disintegrative syndrome unlikely.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was brought to the EEG room. He was asked to stay awake and relax with his eyes closed. Which of the following waves will be detected in his EEG?
questions.solution:
Alpha rhythm waves will be detected in the EEG in an awake and relaxed patient with his eyes closed.

Sleep is comprised of two distinct physiological states: non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep and REM sleep. Stages I to IV make up the NREM sleep with marked lower physiological functions than during wakefulness. During REM sleep, except for eye movement, there is almost a complete loss of skeletal muscle tone. The threshold for arousal from sleep by sensory stimuli is increased during this time. 

Wakefulness: Low-voltage, mixed frequency activity. When eyes are closed, alpha activity is noted. Eye movements and eye blinks are present, with high muscle tonic activity and voluntary movements.

NREM sleep is composed of stages 1 through 4. About 90 minutes after sleep onset, NREM yields to the first REM episode of the night. Non-REM sleep is divided into four stages:

Stage 1: The transition from wakefulness to sleep. EEG shows a low-voltage, mixed-frequency pattern. A theta rhythm (4–7 Hz) is seen during this stage with vertex sharp waves. There are slow eye movements.

Stage 2: Presence of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (7–15 Hz) and K complexes, which are negative sharp waves followed by a positive slow wave. There are no eye movements; muscle tone is reduced.

Stage 3: Presence of a high-amplitude delta rhythm (0.5–4 Hz). There is a further reduction in muscle tone and arousal and no eye movements.

Stage 4: A characteristic pattern of rhythmic slow waves, sometimes referred to as slow-wave sleep. While the occurrence of theta and delta rhythms is normal during sleep. No eye movements and low muscle tone.

REM sleep is characterized by an EEG pattern consisting of low-voltage, random, fast activity with sawtooth waves, as well as theta activity and slow alpha waves.

questions.text: A psychiatrist started his patient on lithium carbonate tablets 900 mg OD for the management of mania. A partial improvement was seen. The serum lithium levels done one week later were found to be 0.5 mEq/L. What should be done next?

choices.text: Wait for improvement with the same dosage

questions.solution:
The given blood lithium levels are inadequate for the treatment of mania. The next best step is to increase the dose of lithium carbonate for the optimal management of acute mania. The treatment of mania requires blood levels to be higher than 0.8 mEq/L.

Lithium is used in the management of bipolar disorder, mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and higher blood levels may cause symptoms of toxicity. Therapeutic drug monitoring is done by measuring lithium levels 12 hours after the previous dose. 

Other options:

900mg OD is generally the starting dose of lithium carbonate. Because of variable excretion and blood levels are variable in individuals. Weekly blood level monitoring is necessary to avoid toxicity and for dose titration.

Wait and watch is not the best option here because the optimal therapeutic level has not been achieved yet. Acute mania gradually resolves in 2 weeks with optimal treatment.

Sodium valproate alone or in combination with antipsychotics is the preferred agent for acute mania because it has a faster onset of action.

questions.text: A 47-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is admitted for the treatment of a fractured tibia. On the 3rd day of admission, he develops severe restlessness and becomes agitated. He has visual and tactile hallucinations. On examination, he is disoriented, diaphoretic and has tachycardia and fever. Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delirium tremens. Administration of lorazepam would be the appropriate treatment for this patient. 

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3-4 days of alcohol withdrawal. Characteristic features are:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and very frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, diaphoresis and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Benzodiazepines such as lorazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours) are given. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options: 

Option A: Phenytoin which is a non-benzodiazepine anti convulsant is usually not helpful in the prevention or treatment of alcohol withdrawal delirium or seizures. 

Option B: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic and is usually avoided in patients with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal due to its propensity to reduce the seizure threshold in alcoholics.

Option C: Fomepizole is used in the treatment of ethylene glycol and methanol intoxication.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of alcohol abuse causes reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone causes reduced reward response to drinking and reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor.

Before prescribing: Evaluate for possible current opioid use; consider a urine toxicology screen for opioids, including synthetic opioids. Obtain liver function tests and follow up periodically.

Acamprosate, naltrexone, and disulfiram are used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Other options:

Option A: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal.

Option B: Acamprosate affects glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems, but its alcohol-related action is unclear.

Option D: Disulfiram inhibits the intermediate metabolism of alcohol which causes a build-up of acetaldehyde and a reaction of flushing, sweating, nausea, and tachycardia if a patient drinks alcohol.

questions.text: A psychiatry resident asks the patient a certain set of questions using the questionnaire given below. What is he trying to assess?
questions.solution:
The given score is MMSE (Mini Mental Status Examination), which assesses cognitive dysfunction as in dementia. 

MMSE is a 30-point questionnaire from categories including orientation, attention, memory, construction, and language, which tallies up to a score of 30. It is easy to administer and takes less than ten minutes to complete. A score of less than 23 points to cognitive impairment. It was devised by Folstein.

Components:

  • Orientation
  • Registration
  • Attention and calculation
  • Recall
  • Language

It can be used to screen for and assess dementia. Some other screening tools are the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA), the tablet-based cognitive assessment tool, and the cognistat.

The picture below shows a sample of the MMSE form:

Advantages:

  • Ease of administration and scoring
  • Less time consuming
  • Can be reliably administered and scored by trained clinic staff
  • Can be tolerated even by very low-functioning patients.

Disadvantages:

  • Influenced by the education level of the patient, i.e. highly educated patients with mild Alzheimer's disease may perform very well on the MMSE, whereas healthy individuals with low education may earn scores in the “impaired” range.
  • May not identify mild cognitive defects or deficits associated with noncortical dementias.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of low mood for the past 2 weeks, reduced socialization, decreased appetite, and inability to sleep for the past 3 months. She also complains of frequent backache and headache, with early morning awakening. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low mood for the past 2 weeks along with reduced appetite, reduced interest in socialization, somatic symptoms, and disturbed sleep, points towards a diagnosis of depression (major depressive disorder). 

The diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. Atleast one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. questions.text: The parents of 6-year-old Ramya were informed that she does not speak at all in school. Her parents are surprised as she seemed completely normal at home and spoke normally. Which of the following features are not likely to be associated with this case?

choices.text: It is related to social anxiety disorder
No risk of delay in language acquisition
Cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a lack of speaking in a child in a social situation, like the school setting, while being normal at home, and thus points towards a diagnosis of selective mutism. It is associated with an increased risk for delayed speech and language acquisition.

Selective mutism refers to the persistent lack of speaking (being mute) in one or more specific social situations. The child is able to speak well in other situations, for example at home. It is related to social anxiety disorder.

Younger children are more likely to develop selective mutism, and it is seen more in girls than boys. Maternal overprotection and anxiety disorders in parents may exacerbate the condition. Some children may develop selective mutism after emotional or physical trauma.

Selectively mute children may have an increased risk for delayed speech and language acquisition and disturbances in auditory processing. However, speech and language problems in children with selective mutism are subtle and are not accountable for the diagnosis of selective mutism. They may also exhibit behavioral disturbances, like temper tan­trums and oppositional behavior at home. They may have symptoms of separation anxi­ety and school refusal.

The diagnosis can be made when a child has clear communication skills but is silent in one or more social situations, like in school. Rarely, a child may be silent at home but communicates normally at school.

Cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment recommended for school-going children with selective mutism. Treatment also involves psychoeducation for the family. Evidence also suggests that SSRIs such as fluoxetine can have beneficial effects in children with selective mutism, similar to social phobia.

questions.text: In a patient with insomnia, agitation, and restlessness, the presence of which of the following symptoms differentiates a manic episode from a hypomanic episode?
questions.solution:
The presence of psychotic features, such as hallucinations, differentiates an episode of hypomania from mania.

The diagnostic criteria for mania as given by DSM-V is:

A. Distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting at least 1 week.

B. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy/activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms are present to a significant degree:

  • Increased self-esteem or grandiosity
  • Decreased need for sleep
  • More talkative than usual or a pressure to keep talking
  • Flight of ideas
  • Distractibility
  • Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation (purposeless non-goal-directed activity)
  • Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences 

These symptoms should either cause marked social distress with a need for hospitalization or psychotic features must be present. These symptoms should not be attributable to other organic disorders or substance abuse.

Hypomania is a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting for at least 4 days. It is similar to a manic episode wherein the patients can portray all of the above-mentioned symptoms but it is not severe enough to cause impairment in social or occupational functioning. No psychotic features are present. In the presence of psychotic features, the episode, by definition, becomes one of mania.

  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline

  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a violent attack. The patient has injuries over her forearm and elbow. On examination, she has injuries over her breasts and inner thighs. Pelvic examination reveals lacerations in the vaginal mucosa. On enquiring about the injuries, the patient is unable to remember the violent incident. Which of the following defense mechanism best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
This patient's history and examination are suggestive of rape, and the patient is repressing the memory of the incident as a means of coping with the anxiety.

Repression is a type of psychological defense mechanism that involves keeping certain thoughts, feelings, or urges out of conscious awareness. The goal of this form of defense is to keep unacceptable desires or thoughts out of the conscious mind in order to prevent or minimize feelings of anxiety.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman was admitted by her parents due to inappropriate behaviour for the past 7 months. In the OPD, she constantly wandered about, pointed aimlessly at her surroundings, burst into laughter without any reason, and made lip-sucking actions. She said that an evil giant was always around her, although no one was near her. Lack of personal care and unorganised behaviour were also noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young woman with inappropriate, bizarre behaviour, aimless activity, presence of delusions, and lack of personal care points towards a diagnosis of schizophrenia, which is likely to be of the hebephrenic or disorganised type.

Hebephrenic schizophrenia (disorganised) has an early onset, generally occurring before 25 years of age. It is characterised by marked regression of behaviour that becomes disorganised and poor contact with reality. Lack of personal care and aimless non-constructive activity is also usually noted. Social behaviour and emotional responses are inappropriate. Sometimes, these patients may burst out laughing or have inappropriate grinning or grimacing behaviour. It has the worst prognosis after simple schizophrenia. 

Schizophrenia is a psychotic disorder with the following criteria: 

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within these 6 months, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms), where 2 or more of the following have to be present (at least one must be among the a, b, or c): 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behaviour
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

3. The rest of the 6 months may include

  • Continuing psychotic symptoms
  • Prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • Residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as

  • Odd beliefs
  • Magical thinking
  • Ideas of reference
  • Odd perceptual experiences
  • Peculiar or concrete thinking
  • Vague speech
  • Odd behaviour
  • Negative symptoms may also be included

5. Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Paranoid schizophrenia:

  • Most common type.
  • Often called paraphrenia in progressive deterioration. 
  • Usual onset in 3rddecade
  • Characterized by delusions of persecution, grandeur, control, etc.
  • Can be associated with hallucination

Catatonic schizophrenia:

  • Marked disturbance in motor function
  • May involve stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing
  • Alteration between extremes of excitement and stupor
  • Best prognosis
  • Term coined by Kahlbaum

Simple schizophrenia:

  • The primary symptom is withdrawal from social and work-related situations
  • Characterized by a gradual, insidious loss of drive and ambition
  • Do not experience persistent hallucinations or delusions
  • Poor prognosis (simple > hebephrenic)

questions.text: An idea intrudes the patient’s consciousness continuously leading to repetitive and purposeful behavior or acts carried out to reduce the intense distress. This act is known as _______
questions.solution:
The obsession will lead to compulsion – which is a repetitive and purposeful behavior or act carried out to reduce the intense distress. Obsession is an idea that continuously intrudes the patient's consciousness.

The characteristics of obsession are:

  • one's own thoughts.
  • ego-alien (ego-dystonic).
  • patients try to resist against it but it leads to further anxiety and distress.
  • the thought is very well known by the patient to be irrational and absurd.

Ego-alien/Ego-dystonic: unwanted and unaccepatable to one's own personality, causing distress.

Ego-syntonic: acceptable to one's own personality. Personality traits are usually ego-syntonic.

questions.text: A young woman was admitted to the psychiatry ward for severe depression with psychotic features, and a complete refusal to eat or drink. During rounds, she was found to be in the position shown in the image below, and resistance was felt in attempting to change her position. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for a patient with severe depression and psychotic features with posturing with waxy flexibility would be electroconvulsive therapy. 

Posturing with waxy flexibility refers to the maintenance of the body position into which they are placed, where any attempt made to change the posture results in resistance felt by the examiner. 

Catatonia is a syndrome characterized by three or more behav­ioral abnormalities such as: 

  • Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  • Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  • Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  • Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  • Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  • Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  • Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  • Grimacing
  • Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  • Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.
  • Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.

 The primary treatment includes:

  • Identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed.
  • Benzodiazepines, especially, lorazepam, are effective in temporarily improving the symptoms.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy is the definitive treatment in cases of life-threatening catatonia (if the patient is unable to eat) or if the patient has developed malignant catatonia.

Other options:

Option C: Lithium is a mood stabiliser used for the management of mania and bipolar depression. 

Option D: Transcranial magnetic stimulation using magnetic energy stimulates the nerve cells in the brain and is used for the treatment of depression.

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.solution:
Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism, unlike introjection, regression, and somatization, which are immature defense mechanisms.

Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism. It means to gratify an impulse by changing the end goal from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one. Sublimation of aggressive impulses generally takes place through games or sports. Sublimation allows instincts to be channelled and not dammed up or diverted. Hence, in sublimation, feelings are acknowledged, modified, and directed toward a socially valued/acceptable goal so that modest instinctual satisfaction is achieved.

  • Anticipation
  • Humor
  • Altruism
  • Asceticism
  • Suppression

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of hearing voices that are asking him to end his life for the past 3 weeks. He speaks in sentences that do not make complete sense. On further probing, he reveals that recently, he had witnessed losing his friend in an accident. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of auditory hallucinations and disorganized speech for the past 3 weeks in a patient with a history of witnessing a traumatic event, a provisional diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder can be made. The presence of these symptoms for less than one month and a history of a traumatic event are the clinchers for this diagnosis. 

A brief psychotic disorder is characterized by a sudden onset of psychotic symptoms that last for at least 1 day and is followed by a complete remission within a month of the appearance of the symptoms. There may also be a precipitating stressor like a traumatic life event. It is commonly seen in women, young people, and those with existing personality disorders.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder, according to DSM-5, requires the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month:

  1. Delusions
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech
  4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

According to ICD-11, this is classified as acute and transient psychotic disorder (ATPD), and the duration of the episode does not last for more than 3 months.

The diagnosis is usually anticipatory or retrospective, after ruling out other mental health disorders and substance abuse. Relapses are seen due to a lack of adherence to medication and should be monitored on a long-term basis. Management of the episode involves hospitalization and initiation of psychotherapy along with pharmacotherapy. Second-generation antipsychotics are considered the first-line treatment option, while benzodiazepines can be used to manage the symptoms in an agitated patient.

Other options:

Option A. When a manic or depressive syndrome develops concurrently with the major symptoms of schizophrenia, with a minimum of 2 weeks of delusions or hallucinations without mood abnormalities, schizoaffective disorder is the appropriate diagnosis.

Option C. A diagnosis of Schizophrenia, which has a similar presentation of psychotic symptoms, requires the continuous presence of these symptoms for a period of at least 6 months.

Option D. Schizophreniform disorder differs from a brief psychotic disorder in that the symptoms have a duration of at least 1 month but less than 6 months.

A 30-year-old man with a Cluster A personality disorder is described by his family members as odd, aloof, and isolated. He lives alone and prefers to work in isolation. Identify the features congruent with the diagnosis.
  1. A history of aggressive verbal behavior 
  2. Isolation is due to fear of criticism or rejection
  3. Appears to be indifferent to the praise or criticism of others
  4. Under stress, there is development of psychotic symptoms
  5. Their capacity to recognize reality is normal
questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is a schizoid personality disorder, and statements 3 and 5 are congruent with the diagnosis. Cluster A includes Schizoid, Schizotypal, and Paranoid personality disorders.

A persons with schizoid personality dis­order are described by others as eccentric, isolated, or lonely. They exhibit lifelong pat­tern of social withdrawal. The onset of this disorder is in childhood or adolescence.

Persons with the disorder prefer solitary jobs so that there is little or no involvement with other people. They are cold, aloof, and show no involvement with everyday events and concerns. They appear to be indifferent to the praise or criticism of others. They pursue their own lives with little or no need for emotional connections and are often unable to directly express anger. Although they appear self-absorbed and lost in daydreams, their capac­ity to recognize reality is normal. 

Men with the disorder may not marry because of the inability to achieve intimacy, while women may passively agree to marry an aggressive man who wants the marriage. 

Differential diagnosis:

  • Schizophrenia, delusional disorder, and affective disorder are characterized by the presence of positive psychotic symptoms
  • Schizotypal personality disorder- Due to poor interpersonal relationships and inappropriate behavior, they are isolated and have very few friends. Under stress, they may decompensate and have brief psychotic symptoms. 
  • Paranoid personality disorder - More social engagement compared with a schizoid personality disorder. They also often have a history of violent verbal behavior and tend to project their feelings on to others
  • Avoidant personality disorders - They are isolated but strongly wish to participate in social activities, which is not seen schizoid personality disor­der. These people isolate themselves and avoid companionship due to their fear of rejection and criticism.

Treatment is with psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. Small dos­es of antipsychotics, antidepressants, and psychostimulants are effective.

questions.text: Which of the following is assessed using the test shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Rorschach inkblot test, which is a projective personality test.

10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblots are shown to the participants. The test is administered in two phases:

  • Free association phase: Participant's response to the cards is recorded
  • Inquiry phase: Participants explain why they formed the impression.

Projective tests:

These tests are based on the principle that when presented with an ambiguous stimulus, such as an inkblot, the patient's responses will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality. The ambiguous stimulus is a sort of screen on which the individual projects his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Projective tests generally do not measure a particular personality type like 'type-A personality' (narrow-band measurement), but rather measure these as a 'whole' (broad-band measurement).

Commonly used projective tests are as follows:

questions.text: In which of the following conditions treatment with fluoxetine should be avoided?

choices.text: Depression associated with Bipolar I Disorder

questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), and among the given options, it is least suited for the management of hypomania as it may precipitate mania and thus should be avoided.

Fluoxetine is used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, postpartum depression, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, generalised anxiety disorders, panic disorder, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder. It is used as an adjunct with Olanzapine (fixed dose) in the management of bipolar depression type I.

The major adverse effects include sexual dysfunction, dry mouth, urinary retention, insomnia, GI disturbances, and weight gain. It should be avoided in patients recovering from depression with suicidal ideation. This is because fluoxetine improves psychomotor withdrawal, permitting the patient to act on preexisting suicidal impulses as they have more energy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with frequent headaches. Following workup, he is diagnosed with migraine headaches. However, he firmly believes that he has a brain tumor. He visits several doctors and undergoes repeated brain imaging, but is still not reassured. His wife mentions that he had previously been visiting multiple doctors for months, after believing he had colon cancer following a few episodes of diarrhea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts a patient misinterpreting his headache and being worried about having a serious illness like brain tumor. This is characteristic of hypochondriasis.

Hypochondriasis, now somatic symptom disorder, is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. Patients believe that they have a serious disease despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the disease, and reassurances from doctors.

They are preoccupied with excessive thinking about their symptoms, leading to high levels of anxiety about their health. They spend excessive time and energy in an attempt to address their health concerns.

The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months. The disorder follows an episodic course separated by long qui­escent periods. Exacerbations of somatic symptoms are associated with psychosocial stressors.

Patients with somatic symptom disorder usually resist psychi­atric treatment. Management involves psychotherapy, regular health checks providing objective evidence of their health, and treatment of any underlying psychiatric conditions like depression.

Other options:

Option A: Conversion disorder now termed functional neurological symptom disorder is a mental disorder in which the patient experiences an involuntary limitation or alteration of physical function that is an expression of a psychological conflict or need, not of a physical disorder.

Option B: Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by persistent preoccupations about perceived flaws in one’s appearance. This causes significant emotional distress and impairment in the patient's functioning. The patient firmly believes that there is some abnormality in their appearance, like a crooked nose, unequal limb length, malformed ears, etc. They may frequently look into the mirror, try various methods to cover up their imaginary flaws, or even avoid stepping out of the house.

Option C: Factitious disorder (Munchausen syndrome) is the intentional production of physical symptoms to seek medical attention. There is no intention to obtain a practical gain. They want to make hospitalization a way of their life.

questions.text: As a part of evaluation, a psychiatrist enumerates all the colors of the rainbow to his patient. The next day, when the patient was asked to recollect these colors, he was unable to recollect the 6th color. The doctor mentioned the first few letters of the color, and then the patient answered. The function of which part of the brain is evaluated here?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, priming is being assessed, which depends on the functioning of the neocortex.

Priming is a form of nondeclarative memory that helps in recognizing words or objects to which the person was exposed previously. It is usually assessed by checking for increased reading speed, faster naming of objects, and faster recollection of getting a clue when presented with previously exposed information.

Memory is usually divided into two forms:

  • Explicit or declarative memory is associated with consciousness or awareness.
  • Implicit or non-declarative memory does not involve awareness and its retention. It does not involve the hippocampus in its processing.

Memory can also be classified as:

Short-term memory- lasts for a few seconds to minutes. Working memory is a form of short-term memory. It keeps the information available, usually for a very short time, until the individual plans some action based on it.

Long-term memory can be recollected after years or even for a lifetime. These memories are stored in various parts of the neocortex. The various types of the memories such as visual, auditory, olfactory, etc., are localized to the cortical regions.

Other options:

Option 1: Striatum forms a part of the basal ganglia and is involved in decision-making functions, such as motor control, emotion, habit formation, and reward.

Option 2: Amygdala, a component of the limbic system, is responsible for the control of emotions, behavior, and memory formation. 

Option 3: Cerebellum is responsible for the coordination of movement, maintaining posture and balance, muscle tone, and motor learning.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

Related Pearl: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.
    • The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.
  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

  • Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?
  • Digit span test.

Concentration:

  • Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?
  • Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account
  • Count backward from 20.
  • Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: A 45-yr-old man with a history of major depressive disorder presents to the psychotherapist after an episode of depression triggered by the death of his wife. By the end of session, the patient unconsciously starts developing feelings towards the therapist similar to the one which he had for his wife. This is an example for____________
questions.solution:
The above-given scenario, in which the patient starts projecting his feelings onto the therapist, is an example of transference.

Transference involves the patient projecting his feelings, thoughts and wishes onto the therapist. It is a process wherein the patient, unconsciously and inappropriately, displaces behavioral and emotional patterns experienced with other people in his or her life (often during childhood) onto individuals in his or her current life.

The therapist needs to recognize that transference may be causative of the patient's behaviors and not react inappropriately by perceiving it as a personal attack by the patient. In the above clinical scenario, the therapist is equated to a partner figure as the man displaces his feelings towards his deceased wife onto the therapist.

When patients in a group direct such feelings toward one another, it is called multiple transferences.

Other options:

Option B. Parapraxis involves the patient unconsciously revealing his feelings via a fault, like a slip of the tongue. It was attributed to unconscious motives by Freud.

Option C. Counter-transference involves the therapist unconsciously displacing onto the patient, behavioral or emotional patterns of a significant figure from the therapist's earlier life. 

Option D. Catharsis is characterized by a sense of relief produced by an emotional response to the expression of suppressed emotions, ideas, and thoughts. In catharsis, the patient reveals information voluntarily and consciously whereas, in parapraxis, patient details are revealed unconsciously, by slip of the tongue.

questions.text:
A young boy who is anticipating his board exams has been increasingly isolated with flat affect for the past 6 months. He has disorganized speech and says he hears a voice telling him that the government is tracking him. On mental status examination, you find that he is depressed. Considering the likely diagnosis, which of the following can be considered a good prognostic factor for him?
  1. Presence of depression
  2. Male sex
  3. Presence of a stressor
  4. Young age of onset
  5. Presence of negative symptoms
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing a flat affect, auditory hallucinations, and disorganized speech is highly suggestive of schizophrenia. The presence of a stressor and depression are good prognostic factors.

Schizophrenia is a psychosis, a type of mental illness characterized by distortions in thinking, perception, emotions, language, sense of self, and behavior.

The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present, with at least one among the symptoms a, b, or c: 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behavior
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

Studies have pointed out that more than half of the patients generally have a poor prognosis. Poor prognostic factors are associated with repeated hospitalizations, exacerbation of symptoms, and suicide attempts. At least one-third of people with schizophrenia experiences complete remission of symptoms. Some people with schizophrenia experience worsening and remission of symptoms periodically throughout their lives, others a gradual worsening of symptoms over time.

Based on the predominant clinical presentation, schizophrenia is divided into five subtypes: paranoid, disorganized, undifferentiated, catatonic, and residual. Antipsychotics form the mainstay of treatment, while psychotherapy is used as an adjunct.

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student came to OPD with intermittent episodes of the feeling of impending doom, accompanied by intense perspiration. Usually, the episodes occur prior to her exams. Which of the following agents has the most rapid onset of action against her condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is panic disorder. Benzodiazepines have the most rapid onset of action in panic, with the onset happening often within the first week.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort. Recurrent panic attacks for more than one month are classified as panic disorder. Panic attacks can occur in mental disorders other than panic disorder, particu­larly in specific phobia, social phobia, and post-traumatic stress disorder.

Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam and lorazepam have been widely used for panic disorder. They are often used as a first agent while the serotonergic drug is up-titrated to therapeutic levels. Benzodiazepines are preferred for short-term therapy as long-term use can often lead to dependence and abuse.

Clinically, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and clomipramine are preferred over benzodiazepines, monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), and tricyclic and tetracyclic drugs in terms of effectiveness, long-term therapy, and tolerance of adverse effects.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of waking up in the night and screaming for the past 4 months. The episodes were regular at around 10 pm every night, but the boy was not able to recall the episode happening and was inconsolable during the episode. He started going to school 5 months ago and had a liking for violent video games. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is where a boy who wakes up in the middle of the night screaming and does not recall the event in the morning is experiencing sleep terrors or night terrors.

Sleep terrors/night terrors/pavor noc­turnus/incubus are sleep arousal disorders that are seen in stages 3 and 4 of non-rapid eye movement sleep. They are characterised by recurrent episodes, usually occurring in the first third of the night. The disorder may be familial and is mostly seen in young children and rarely in adults.

Clinical features include:

  • The patient experiences intense fear, characterised by screaming and relative unresponsiveness to the efforts of others to comfort the patient
  • There are autonomic signs like mydriasis, tachycardia, rapid breathing, and sweating during each episode, suggestive of intense fear.
  • There is no memory of the episode, causing confusion and disorientation if awakened.
  • There may be incoherent vocalisations
  • Sleep terrors are usually devoid of any images or may contain only fragments of very brief, frightening static images.
  • There are no signs of temporal lobe epilepsy or other sei­zure disorders

Precipitants of sleep terrors can be:

  • Fever
  • Sleep deprivation
  • CNS depressant withdrawal.
  • History of a traumatic experience
  • Psychiatric issues

Treatment involves:

  • Universal sleep hygiene
  • Behav­ioral techniques
  • Stimu­lus control therapy
  • Lucid dream therapy
  • Cognitive therapy

Other options:

Nightmare disorder/dream anxiety attacks: Terrifying dreams that occur in the rapid eye movement stage of sleep. They pro­duce sympathetic activation to awaken the patient to wakefulness, where the dream can be recollected. They are commonly seen in young children and adults with post-traumatic stress disorder.

Precipitating factors include:

  • Traumatic events
  • Medications like L-DOPA and beta blockers
  • Withdrawal from REM suppressant medications
  • Drug or alcohol abuse
  • Sleep deprivation

Sleep-related groaning/Catathrenia: Chronic condition characterized by prolonged, frequent loud groans during sleep, which occur at any stage of sleep. It may begin during childhood and is not related to any psychiatric or physiologic abnormalities. There is no known treatment.

Sleep-related hallucinations: Visual images that are difficult to differentiate from dreams, occurring at sleep onset (hypnagogic) or on awakening (hypnopompic) from sleep. They are com­mon in patients with narcolepsy. They usually happen with abrupt awakening and without remembrance of dreaming. The images may be frightening, vivid, immobile and usually disappear when a light is turned on.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man who was treated with haloperidol for delirium developed fever, tachycardia, increased blood pressure, muscle stiffness, and altered mental status. Investigations revealed elevated levels of creatine phosphokinase (CPK). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features in a patient who has been administered haloperidol, are most likely suggestive of the neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening complication that can occur anytime during antipsychotic treatment. Haloperidol is known to cause NMS. The condition may occur within 24-72 hrs after initiation of the treatment, and if untreated, may last for 10 to 14 days.

Clinical features include motor and behavioral symptoms like muscular rigidity, dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agita­tion. Autonomic symptoms include fever, diaphore­sis, and increased pulse and blood pressure.

Investigations reveal elevated levels of WBC count, creatinine phosphokinase (CPK), myoglobin, and liver enzymes. Occasionally, myoglobinuria may be seen in patients who develop acute renal failure.

Dantrolene and bromocriptine are commonly used for the treatment. Amantadine may be used in some cases. Electroconvulsive therapy may also be used. 

Other options:

Option A: Serotonin syndrome occurs due to an increase of plasma serotonin to toxic levels, due to concurrent administration of SSRI and an MAO inhibitor, L-tryptophan or lithium. The patients initially present with diarrhea and restlessness. As the condition worsens, they develop extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability, myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, and rigidity. There may be delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardio­ vascular collapse, and death in the worst cases.

Option B: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal, irregular, involuntary choreoathetoid movements of the muscles of the head, limbs, and trunk. Perioral movement is most common. The condition usually develops as a delayed response to antipsychotics, about 6 months after treatment.

Option C: Hypersensitivity reaction to haloperidol may include anaphylactic reaction, angioedema, rash, urticaria, face edema, laryngeal edema, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

questions.text: A 23-year old healthcare worker presented with a feeling of depressed mood that lasts most of the day, from her late adolescence till date. She has feelings of worthlessness, has no interest to do anything and stays away from interacting with others. She has never experienced a manic episode and does not have any agitation, suicidal thoughts or any other medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of persistent depressed mood since adolescence, that lasts most of the day, with feelings of worthlessness, withdrawal from society, loss of interest without psychomotor agitation, suicidal thoughts or any other medical history is suggestive of dysthymia.

Dysthymia is a persis­tent depressive disorder that is characterised by the presence of:

  • Insidious onset
    • Early: <21 years, more common
    • Late: > 21 years
  • Depressed mood that lasts most of the day, almost continuously.
  • Associated feelings of inadequacy, guilt, irritability, and anger
  • Withdrawal from society
  • Loss of interest, inactiv­ity, lack of productivity
  • Inertia, lethargy, and anhedonia are characteristi­cally worse in the morning

The disorder is more common in women and young people. It frequently coexists with other mental disorders, like major depressive disorder, anxiety disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder. 

The DSM-5 diagnosis criteria for dysthymia includes:

  • Presence of a depressed mood most of the time for at least 2 years (or 1 year for children and adolescents)
  • Presence of 2 or more features of poor appetite/overeating, insomnia/hypersomnia, low energy, low self-esteem, feelings of hopelessness or poor concentration.
  • Should not have symptoms that are part of major depressive disorder like disturbances in appetite and libido, psychomotor agitation or suicidal thoughts
  • Absence of any other medical illness or substance use that can cause this condition.
 

Treatment includes:

  1. Cognitive therapy
  2. Behaviour therapy
  3. Insight oriented psychoanalytic therapy
  4. Interpersonal therapy
  5. Family and group therapies
  6. Pharmacotherapy with SSRIs, venlafaxine and bupropion

Other options:

Double Depression is a condition with the presence of major depressive disorder along with dysthymia.

Cyclothymia is a chronic, fluctuating mood disturbance with many periods of hypomania and of depression.

Patients with minor depressive disorder have a euthymic mood in between the episodes, but patients with dysthymia have virtually no euthymic periods.

questions.text: A middle aged man comes with complaints of early ejaculation. He reports that ejaculation usually occurs within 15 seconds of vaginal penetration. Which phase of the normal sexual cycle does this disorder belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of ejaculation within 15 seconds of vaginal penetration is suggestive of premature ejaculation. It is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the normal sexual cycle.

In premature ejaculation, there is a persistent or recurrent achievement of orgasm and ejaculation before the patient actually wishes to. Difficulty in ejaculatory control can be associated with anxiety regarding the sex act, unconscious fears about the vagina, or negative cultural conditioning. According to DSM-5, it is classified as:

  • Mild if ejaculation occurs within approximately 30 sec­onds to 1 minute of vaginal penetration
  • Moderate if ejaculation occurs within approximately 15 to 30 seconds of vaginal pen­etration
  • Severe if ejaculation occurs at the start of sexual activity or within approximately 15 seconds of vaginal penetra­tion.

Sexual response is a true psycho-physiological experience. Normally, men and women experience a sequence of physiological responses to sexual stimulation. The phases of the normal sexual response cycle are:

  • Desire phase - consists of sex fantasies and the desire to have sex
  • Excitement/Arousal phase - heightened excitement before orgasm (longest phase)
  • Orgasmic phase - a subjective perception of a peak physical reaction and release occurs, along with a feeling of well-being (shortest phase). It is marked by ejaculation.
  • Resolution phase - return to the baseline.

Following orgasm, men experience a refractory period during which they cannot be restimulated to further arousal. Women do not have a refractory period and can experience multiple, successive orgasms.

Disorders of the orgasm phase also include other conditions like female orgasmic disorder and delayed ejaculation.

Other options:

Option A: Desire phase disorder includes male hypoactive sexual desire disorder. It is characterized by a deficiency or absence of sexual fantasies and a desire for sexual activity. This should be present for at least 6 months.

Option B: Arousal disorders include female sexual arousal disorder and male erectile disorder. Women with sexual arousal disorder are unable to feel sexual interest or arousal. Male erectile disorder refers to difficulty obtaining and/or maintaining an erection during sexual activity. There may or may not be decreased erectile rigidity.

Option D: The resolution phase lasts for 10-15 minutes. If no orgasm is achieved, it can last for 1/2 -1 day. It is marked by full detumescence in 5-30 minutes. Detumescence is the release of vascular activity and muscle tone after orgasm.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male prefers to be detached, does not mingle with people, and often remains alone. He does not experience pleasure and is rather preoccupied with himself and his own fantasy world. This personality type will show__________
questions.solution:
A young male who is a loner by choice and emotionally cold comes under schizoid personality. Individuals with schizoid personality have low novelty seeking.

Novelty seeking (NS) is a temperament trait in the Cloninger’s model of personality and refers to the tendency to be intensely exhilarated or excited in response to novel stimuli.

  • Individuals high in novelty seeking are quick-tempered, curious, easily bored, impulsive, extravagant, and disorderly.
  • High novelty seeking is related to addiction, ADHD and impulsivity.
  • Cluster B personality disorders like borderline, histrionic, narcissistic and antisocial have high novelty seeking behavior.

Low novelty seeking:

  • Persons low in novelty seeking are slow tempered, uninquiring, stoical, reflective, frugal, reserved, tolerant of monotony, and orderly.
  • Individual with schizoid personality is a markedly detached person who stays alone in introspection and lives in his own world of fantasy. This is associated with having a cold attitude.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for histrionic personality disorder is ________.
questions.solution:
Psychoanalytically oriented psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for histrionic personality disorder. Pharmacotherapy can be used as an adjunctive for targeting specific symptoms (e.g. SSRIs for co-morbid depression).

Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP) and mentalization-based therapy (MBT) are the various types of psychotherapy used, especially, for the treatment of borderline personality disorder.

While psychotherapy remains the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder, there is no consensus as to which particular therapy (viz. DBT, TFP, or MBT) is superior to the others.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents for a health check-up, during which the doctor finds that he is reluctant to talk about his illnesses. He is suspicious that the information will be used to harm him. He does not trust his family either for the same reason. He does not forgive easily and bears grudges. What is the type of personality disorder that he has?
questions.solution:
The given history of long-standing suspiciousness, not trusting people, and bearing grudges for insults is suggestive of paranoid personality disorder.

Paranoid personality disorder, a part of cluster A personality disorders, is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful of perceived threats and deceit and often read hidden demeaning or threatening meanings into benign remarks. They are reluctant to confide in others due to the fear that the information they provide will be used against them maliciously.

They tend to be extremely jealous, hostile, argumentative, and defensive. Their paranoia prevents them from establishing any overly involved relationship. They persistently bear grudges and can get irritable and angry easily. They use the defense mechanism of projection by displacing their insecurities on others. 

They may not be willing to accept that they need psychiatric help. Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice. Care should be taken by the therapist to not behave defensively if accused of making a mistake. Pharmacotherapy is generally used to deal with anxiety and agitation. Diazepam is used as an anxiolytic, while antipsychotics like haloperidol or pimozide may be required to deal with agitation.

Other options:

Option A: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder are usually eccentric and isolated. They neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They always choose to be alone and lack close friends. They are emotionally cold and appear indifferent to praise or criticism.

Option B: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder appear odd and strange to surrounding people. They have ideas of reference, odd or magical thinking, inappropriate or constricted affect, and suspiciousness.

Option D: Individuals with histrionic personality disorder have excessive emotional and attention-seeking behaviour. They are uncomfortable in situations where they are not the centre of attraction. They also have inappropriate, sexually seductive, or provocative behaviour. They try to use their physical appearance to draw others' attention.

questions.text: You are a psychiatry junior resident who is called to the medicine ward to assess a 68-year-old woman for suspected signs of delirium. You proceed to evaluate for delirium using the confusion assessment method. The presence of which of the following is not required for the diagnosis of delirium in this method?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient suspected of delirium, the confusion assessment method (CAM) diagnostic algorithm can be used as a screening tool. The presence of signs of psychomotor activity is not required for the diagnosis of delirium in this method.

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is used as a screening tool and the diagnosis of delirium requires the presence of:

  • Acute onset and fluctuating course (Options A & D), 
  • Inattention (Option C), and
  • either disorganized thinking or an altered level of consciousness

Other screening tools that can aid in identifying patients with delirium are:

  • Nursing Delirium Screening Scale (NuDESC)
  • Organic Brain Syndrome Scale
  • Delirium Rating Scale
  • ICU version of the CAM
  • Delirium Detection Score

Delirium, a life-threatening but reversible CNS disorder, is characterized by an acute decline in the level of consciousness and global impairment of cognitive functions. It has an acute onset (hours to days) and prodromal symptoms like restlessness and fearfulness can be seen. with a fluctuating course. The episodes are usually brief lasting from days to weeks and follow a fluctuating course.

The hallmark feature is a decline in the level of consciousness, particularly altered attention. It is accompanied by impairment in cognitive function manifesting as disorientation and decreased memory. Abnormalities of mood, perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations, and behavioral abnormalities are common psychiatric manifestations. 

Abnormal psychomotor activity is also seen, although it is not used during assessment via the Confusion Assessment Method (CAM). Other clinical features include sleep cycle impairment, worsening of symptoms at night (sundowning), and neurological manifestations like autonomic instability.

The major neuroanatomical area and the major neurotransmitter hypothesized are the reticular formation and acetylcholine, respectively. The precipitating factors include drugs like sedatives-hypnotics and narcotics, neurological diseases like meningitis and stroke, intercurrent illnesses like infections and hypoxia, environmental stressors, and major surgeries.

Delirium is a clinical diagnosis and screening tools like CAM are used for it. The primary goal of treatment is to identify the underlying cause and rapid improvement can be seen once it is eliminated. Management requires prompt supportive care. Antipsychotics like haloperidol, for managing psychotic symptoms, and short-acting benzodiazepines like lorazepam, for managing insomnia, may be required. Delirium is associated with high morbidity, and thus, the predisposing and precipitating factors should be identified to prevent an episode of delirium.
