questions.text: On being asked "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?" the patient replies "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa." What is this type of response known as?
questions.solution:
As the patient has given a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly; it is tangentiality. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

Circumstantiality: The patient includes irrelevant details and goes on talking in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

Example: Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"
Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper, and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

Derailment: A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

Example: "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

Desultory thoughts: Speech is grammatically correct; however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

Example: My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presented with amenorrhea, nausea, and vomiting. She was apprehensive about being pregnant after having unprotected sex. She gave a history of having undergone tubal ligation 8 months ago and admitted having a low mood following it. On examination, her breasts were enlarged with pigmented areola and contained milk. The abdomen was distended and a pigmented line was observed from the umbilicus to the pubis. The urine pregnancy test was negative and the pelvic ultrasound was unremarkable. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given history of amenorrhea presently and tubal ligation 8 months ago, clinical findings of breast enlargement and linea nigra, along with a negative pregnancy test point towards a diagnosis of pseudocyesis for which psychotherapy is recommended. 

Pseudocyesis is characterized by the presence of the classic symptoms of pregnancy- amenorrhea, nausea, breast enlarge­ment and pigmentation, abdominal distention, and labor pains, in a nonpregnant woman. It signifies the ability of the psyche (mind) to dominate the soma (body).

A true somatic delusion may be present in the patient but it is usually resolved after a negative urine pregnancy test result or pelvic ultrasound. Predisposing factors like a pathological wish or fear of pregnancy, gender or sexuality-related conflicts, and a history of miscarriage or tubal ligation, are usually present.

Management involves psychotherapy during or after such a presentation, to determine the underlying psychological abnormality and treat it.

Note: Couvade syndrome is a related phenomenon seen in some cultures where the would-be-father undergoes simulated labor. However, in those cultures, couvade is a normal phenomenon.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes for a follow-up, 1 week after her first child was born. Her husband reports that his wife appears uninterested in taking care of the baby, has sudden crying outbursts and seems sad for no reason for the last 2 days. Her sleep is disturbed and she feels fatigued. She is able to carry out the daily chores and enjoys watching television like before. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has mild depressive symptoms within the first week of delivery. So the most likely diagnosis is postpartum blues.

Postpartum blues, also called maternity blues, typically develop within one week of delivery, usually on the fourth or fifth postpartum day. The affected mothers are emotionally labile and the symptoms include changes in mood, sudden crying outbursts, and a lack of interest in the baby. They may also have insomnia, anxiety, poor concentration, and irritability.

These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously within 10-14 days. 

Management involves reassurance, education, and support. The patient must be followed-up and assessed for the possible development of a major depressive disorder.

Other options:

Option B: Symptoms should persist for >2 weeks to make the diagnosis of post-partum depression. A minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder i.e. impaired sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation must be present. This patient is able to do her daily chores, enjoys watching TV, has a good appetite, and does not have guilt or suicidal ideation. Although this patient has disturbed sleep and fatigue, these are common physiological postpartum findings.

Option C: Post-partum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset is 2-3 weeks postpartum. The predominant symptoms are hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by signs such as insomnia, restlessness, labile mood, and agitation. Lithium, often in combina­tion with an antidepressant, is the treatment of choice.

Option D: Episodes of delirium in the postpartum period are characterized by a fluctuating level of awareness or attention. In this patient, there is no altered sense of awareness.

Note:  Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady visited a psychiatrist with complaints of excessive fear of closed spaces. She avoids using an elevator or closing her washroom door. questions.text: A 22-year-old woman complains of excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden bouts of sleep. The symptoms began at the age of 11 and have been worsening. She couldn’t stay awake during her classes or exams and often dozed off standing up, while working. Eventually, she developed episodes of sudden loss of muscle tone, precipitated by strong emotions. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of narcolepsy.

It is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  3. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  4. Sleep paralysis

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM-sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep (sleep onset REM).

Treatment: 

  • Sleep hygiene
  • Scheduled naps
  • Avoidance of alcohol and drugs that cause drowsiness
  • Drugs:

    • Methylphenidate

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of severe insomnia. She has been feeling ants walking over the skin of her legs, and an irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep. The drug of choice for treating this condition would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with insomnia feeling ants walking over her skin along with an irresistible urge to move her legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep is indicative of restless leg syndrome and gabapentin is the first-line choice of treatment for this condition.    

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. Moving the leg or walking alleviates the symptoms. This cycle sometimes continues for hours during the night and can result in profound insomnia. Decreased dopamine receptor expression and mild dopaminergic hypofunction are usually noted in these patients.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to your clinic by her friend with complaints that she eats large amounts of food when she is alone and food wrappers are often found hidden in her room. Once or twice a week, she vomits after having a large meal. On examination, erosion of teeth enamel is noted and her BMI is found to be 19. What is considered the benchmark first-line treatment for her condition?

choices.text: Eating and vomiting prevention as part of exposure and response prevention

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting, with normal weight, is suggestive of bulimia nervosa. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is the benchmark, first-line treatment for bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is characterized by a morbid fear of weight gain and episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory purging behaviors. DSM 5 diagnostic criteria for bulimia nervosa are:

  • A recurrent episode of binge eating characterized by
    • eating relatively a large amount of food in a short span of time
    • lack of control during the episode
  • Recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviors in order to prevent weight gain, such as self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, or excessive exercise.
  • This behavior is present at least once a week for 3 months
  • There is fear of becoming fat or wanting to lose weight
  • It does not occur during the periods of anorexia nervosa

It can be treated with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy.

CBT involves disrupting the cycle of repeated binge eating-purging and changing the patient's beliefs about food, body weight, body image, etc. Drugs usually used in the treatment of bulimia nervosa are fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) is based on the psychological significance of the cognitive triad i.e. people's beliefs about themselves, their personal world (including the people in their lives), and their future. Problematic and biased interpretations related to this cognitive triad may lead to excessive emotional distress. CBT is used in the treatment of depression, phobia, anxiety & panic disorders, OCD, personality disorders, and somatoform disorders.

The three components of cognitive therapy are: 

  • Didactic aspects: Explaining to patients the cognitive triad, schemas, and faulty logic. The therapist must explain all the aspects of treatment.
  • Cognitive techniques: These involve four steps-
    • Eliciting automatic thoughts- Asking the patient about the thought that causes the emotional reaction in them.
    • Testing the validity of the automatic thoughts
    • Identifying the general maladaptive assumptions
    • Testing the validity of maladaptive assumptions
  • Behavioral techniques like relaxation techniques, cognitive rehearsal, self-reliance, etc.

Other options:

Option A. Dialectical behavioral therapy(DBT) is a long-term behavioral intervention that is shown to reduce suicidal behavior in adults and has also shown efficacy in borderline personality disorder. The goal of the therapy is to improve interpersonal relationships and decrease self-destructive behavior using techniques that involve advice, metaphor, storytelling, and confrontation.

Option C. Systemic desensitization is based on the behavioral principle of counterconditioning whereby the person overcomes anxiety elicited by a situation or an object by approaching the feared situation gradually, in a relaxed state. It is useful in phobias, obsessions, compulsions, and some sexual disorders. It has three steps: relaxation training, hierarchy construction, and desensitization of the stimulus.

Option D. Exposure and response prevention is a strategy within CBT that is effective in the management of OCD. It is also useful in other conditions like tics.

questions.text: "Deficits are more severe for information that was most recently learned." This applies best to:
questions.solution:
"Deficits are more severe for information that was most recently learned" - is known as Ribot's law. This applies best to retrograde amnesia.

Ribot's Law states that "Deficits are more severe for information that was most recently learned," i.e.,  during incidents of retrograde amnesia, recent memories are more likely to be lost than remote memories. Ex:- If an incident causing retrograde amnesia occurs at 30 years of age, the memories acquired at 28 years of age may be more severely affected than those memories acquired at 20 years of age or earlier.

Dissociative amnesia is characterized by extensive and severe amnesia with an inability to recall important autobiographical information. The amnesia is predominantly retrograde with minimal anterograde amnesia. It usually follows severe emotional trauma, interpersonal conflicts, and other stressful events, such as sexual abuse, loss of a loved one, loss of livelihood, etcetera. Clinically, the presentation is quite dramatic with significant impairment in social, personal, and occupational functioning. In order for a diagnosis of dissociative amnesia to be made, it is imperative to rule out substance use, and other neurological and psychological conditions that may lead to a presentation similar to dissociative amnesia. 

It is further categorized into the following types:

  • Selective amnesia: Ability to remember some, but not all of the events occurring during a circumscribed period of time.
  • Localized amnesia: Inability to recall all events in a circumscribed period of time.
  • Generalized amnesia: Failure to recall one’s entire life.
  • Continuous amnesia: Failure to recall successive events as they occur.
  • Systematized amnesia: Amnesia for certain categories of memory, such as all memories relating to one’s family or to a particular person.

Dissociative fugue is characterized by a sudden, unintended, and unexpected travel to a place away from home, or workplace, or another place involved in one's daily repertoire. It is usually brief, lasting few hours to days, and is generally reversible. It is commonly associated with dissociative amnesia. In addition to amnesia, these patients may also experience confusion, trance-like behaviors, depersonalization, derealization, and conversion symptoms. It may recur in some patients.

It is important to note that dissociative fugue was deleted as a major diagnostic category in DSM-5. It is instead declared as a subtype or specifier of disso­ciative amnesia.

Treatment of dissociative amnesia and dissociative fugue is mainly with psychotherapy.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his wife. The patient accuses his wife of cheating on him despite the wife denying it. The patient constantly keeps checking his wife's phone and has hacked into her social media account on multiple occasions previously. The wife says that the patient has become very jealous and insecure. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is suffering from Othello syndrome. It is a rare psychiatric condition where a person has morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy and suspects a faithful partner of infidelity.

Delusional Misidentification Syndromes:

Capgras syndrome: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Fregoli syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: This is a very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppelganger syndrome: This is a delusion of subjective doubles, where the person feels that he/she has his/her own impostor (doppelganger). 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.
